author: nero_eth
content:
Continuing the discussion during yesterday's breakout on adding `gas_used` values into the BAL, I tried modelling it here:
https://hackmd.io/@Nerolation/HJe-yyc1Zl

author: draganrakita
content: I dont think it is worth exploring this any more, we are talking about worst case (drop of 25% is parallel exec is nothing if we have 3x reduced the time) of not usual case (one big tx at the end of block). And optimizing this not usual case is not worth imo.

author: nero_eth
content:
It's true that everyday blocks look different but we have to consider the worst-cases here. This means that in the future, to measure worst-case blocks execution times, we need to think in the realms of "ordered list scheduling" vs "greedy scheduling" with the latter being simpler to reason about.
Where are the 25% from? 
In my model it's 39% at 8 cores and a gas limit of 300M.

author: draganrakita
content:
Optimal number of gas on 300M block on 8 cores is 37.5M, this is 8x the speed up
worst case if one core is 53.5 (37.5+16) this is still 5.6x speedup.

author: draganrakita
content:
Optional number of gas on 300M block on 4 cores, is 75M, this is 4x the speed up
worst ase if on one core is 91M (75+16) this is 3.2x

author: nero_eth
content: I see! Wouldn't you say going from 8x to 5.6x is a quite significant drop that limits further scaling as we focus on worst-cases?

author: draganrakita
content: It is big, maybe it will be good to consider, but speeding up verification by 8x does not help with building of block, and this factor is not going to be exact with all that is happening on one machine, having leeway is maybe good.

author: nero_eth
content: true but for local builders nothing would get worse at least and those that have the resources to build that big blocks would probably be happy if we let them. Agree, we need leeway but this feels like we're leaving potential on the table.

author: nero_eth
content: I tend to agree with you <@429719902363058177> . Especially since the worst-cases under "greedy + reordering" is not significantly better, it might just nbe worth it.

author: nero_eth
content:
I still need to think about it more, but hereâ€™s how it looks so far:
If we assume homogeneous node hardware (same number of cores; which might be overly unrealistic already) and validators gradually raise the gas limit to fully exploit greedy scheduling with reordering, we can achieve around 87.5% efficiency gains. If we can actually leverage that, not sure.
In contrast, with ordered-list scheduling, the worst-case execution time scales linearly with the block gas limit - which might be nice, even though it might leave some efficiency potential on the table.

author: draganrakita
